description:
But let's start with the election. Now if politicians like ambiguity, markets like certainty. And that's exactly what the British electorate has now delivered. It's not a massive majority for the Conservatives but one that assures the financial world that at least they know who will be controlling the purse strings for the next five years. And it's a lot better than the days of coalition horse-trading that everyone expected. More importantly it also means there're no plans to ease cutbacks in public spending or end the non-dom status of wealthy Britons who live overseas or break up the big utility companies. So general euphoria in the city. Dominic Laurie went to find out.

So I'm in the CMC Markets' trading floor here in the city of London and it wasn't supposed to be like this, the atmosphere, that there was supposed to be confusion, nervousness, instead we have a government with a majority. Michael Hewson is a chief market analyst from CMC Markets. Just tell us what the markets are doing to this quite unexpected result.

Markets are up across the board. Pound is up, FTSE 100 opened higher, the FTSE 250's gone to a record high and the pound has rebounded quite strongly as well.

Why has the pound risen over the last 24 hours?

Essentially markets like continuity. I think there was an awful lot of concern that we'd be waking up this morning to a potential Labour government with an awful lot of what I would call, anti-business policies which the markets and investors tend to be fairly uncomfortable with.

description:
